name: Chisinau

name: Ankara

name: Istanbul

art: Osman Hamdi Bey - The Turtle Trainer

name: Manchester
familyClue: We saw Josie Long here together.
wikipediaSummary: Manchester is a major city in northwest England with a rich industrial heritage. It was a driving force of the Industrial Revolution and remains a hub for culture, media, higher education, and music. Known for its architecture, sports, and pioneering role in science and technology, it has evolved into one of the UK‚Äôs most dynamic metropolitan centers.
art: L. S. Lowry - Coming from the Mill
Ford Madox Brown - Work
Pierre Adolphe Valette - Albert Square, Manchester
weirdFacts: The world‚Äôs first programmable computer was built here in 1948.
The atom was first split in a university lab in this city in 1917.
It was the birthplace of the world‚Äôs first professional football league.

name: York
familyClue: I met the most important person in the world here.
wikipediaSummary: A historic walled city in northern England, rich in Roman, Viking, and medieval heritage. It has been a key religious and political center for centuries, known for its cathedral, preserved streets, and layers of visible history.
art: William Etty - The Sirens and Ulysses
weirdFacts: There are said to be more ghosts per square mile here than anywhere else in Europe.
A pub in the city has a Roman road running directly beneath its cellar.
Its cathedral took over 250 years to complete.

name: Cambridge

art: Sir Stanley Spencer - The Resurrection, Cookham (studied here)
Quentin Blake - Illustrations for university presses
weirdFacts: A mathematical bridge is held together by bolts, despite a legend claiming it originally wasn‚Äôt.
A famous apple tree here inspired the discovery of gravity‚Äîthough the original was replaced.
Students once floated a car onto a college roof as a prank, where it stayed for weeks.

name: Oxford
familyClue: There's a story museum we have taken our firstborn to here.
wikipediaSummary: A historic university city in southern England, home to one of the world‚Äôs oldest and most prestigious universities. It has influenced education, politics, and culture for centuries and features a blend of medieval and modern architecture.
art: J. M. W. Turner - High Street, Oxford
William Holman Hunt - The Light of the World
weirdFacts: An exam tradition requires students to wear carnations of different colors depending on progress.

The oldest university building dates back to the 11th century and still holds lectures.

name: Bath
familyClue: I try to get the kids to pronounce this correctly, often.
wikipediaSummary: A UNESCO World Heritage city in southwest England, founded by the Romans for its natural hot springs. It became a fashionable spa town in the 18th century and remains known for its Georgian architecture and historic baths.

weirdFacts: It‚Äôs the only place in the UK where you can bathe in naturally hot mineral water.

Roman engineers built advanced lead piping that still exists beneath modern streets.

name: Edinburgh
familyClue: We tried to stay in a B&B here but went next door.
wikipediaSummary: The capital of Scotland, known for its medieval Old Town, elegant Georgian New Town, and a world-famous arts festival. It is a center of culture, education, and history, built on volcanic hills overlooking the sea.
art: Henry Raeburn - The Skating Minister
David Allan - The Origin of Painting
Sir Eduardo Paolozzi - Sculptural works exhibited internationally
weirdFacts: A cannon is fired from the castle every day at 1 PM as a time signal.

name: Geneva

art: Jean-√âtienne Liotard - The Chocolate Girl
weirdFacts: The world‚Äôs tallest water jet shoots 140 meters into the air here.

name: Nyon
familyClue: You founded a library here.

name: Lausanne

name: Munich

name: Aachen

name: Nancy
familyClue: We saw a fabulous light show here
wikipediaSummary: A city in northeastern France known for its elegant 18th-century architecture and role as the heart of the Art Nouveau movement. Its historic center, centered on Place Stanislas, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
art: √âmile Gall√© - Art Nouveau glass and furniture inspired by local flora and produced in the city
weirdFacts: Its central square was once a royal project linking two rival cities by design.
The local university was relocated here from a city annexed by Germany in 1871.
A giant replica of the Eiffel Tower was once built here entirely out of crystal.

name: Lyon
familyClue: USA win! Netherlands in the bin!
wikipediaSummary: A historic city in southeastern France at the confluence of the Rh√¥ne and Sa√¥ne rivers, known for its Roman ruins, silk trade, and reputation as the gastronomic capital of France.
art: Tony Garnier - Urban designs and murals inspired by the city‚Äôs industrial quarters
weirdFacts: The world‚Äôs first cinematographic film was shot here in 1895 by the Lumi√®re brothers.
Many old houses are connected by secret passageways once used by silk workers.
Its residents are nicknamed after a small red hat worn by local revolutionaries.

name: Nice
familyClue: You were first the Mummy Crab here.
wikipediaSummary: A Mediterranean city on the French Riviera known for its sunny climate, artistic heritage, and historic role as a retreat for European nobility. It remains a major center for tourism and culture.
art: Henri Matisse - View of Nice
Marc Chagall - Biblical Message paintings (inspired by the region)
weirdFacts: The seafront promenade was originally funded by English expatriates fleeing a cold winter.
An annual carnival has been celebrated here for nearly 700 years.
The beach is made entirely of smooth pebbles, not sand.

name: Toulouse
wikipediaSummary: A vibrant city in southwestern France nicknamed the 'Pink City' for its terracotta buildings. It is a major aerospace hub and cultural center blending southern charm with industrial innovation.
art: Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec - Posters depicting Parisian nightlife, from a family rooted in the region
weirdFacts: Many buildings are built from pinkish brick, giving the city its nickname.
The world‚Äôs first Concorde aircraft was assembled nearby.
A local museum displays early airplanes in a converted slaughterhouse.

name: Bordeaux
wikipediaSummary: Bordeaux is a historic city in southwestern France, renowned for its wine production, elegant architecture, and vibrant cultural scene. The city has played an important role in the region's history and continues to be a center of commerce, education, and tourism.
art: Odilon Redon - The Cyclops
Rosa Bonheur - The Horse Fair
weirdFacts: It has over 350 historic buildings and monuments, earning it UNESCO World Heritage status.
The city's wine trade made it one of Europe's wealthiest cities in the 18th century.
Its port was once the busiest in the country, handling wine exports worldwide.

name: Lille
familyClue: We first saw the Moon here.
wikipediaSummary: A northern French city with Flemish roots and a strong industrial heritage, now known for its culture, art museums, and as a key transport hub connecting Paris, London, and Brussels by Eurostar.
art: √âdouard Pignon - Industrial landscapes reflecting the region‚Äôs workers
weirdFacts: An enormous annual flea market attracts over two million visitors each year.
It was once part of Flanders and still shows strong Flemish architectural influences.
Its central train station connects directly to London via the Eurostar in under 90 minutes.

name: Barcelona
familyClue: You have visited here with only one of our children.
wikipediaSummary: A Mediterranean coastal city known for its unique architecture by Antoni Gaud√≠, rich cultural heritage, and vibrant urban life. It is the capital of Catalonia and a major European destination for art and design.
art: Antoni Gaud√≠ - Sagrada Fam√≠lia
Joan Mir√≥ - Dona i Ocell (Woman and Bird)
Pablo Picasso - Las Meninas series (created while living in the city)
weirdFacts: The city once turned down hosting the Eiffel Tower before Paris accepted it.
Its beaches are artificial, created for the 1992 Olympics.
A major street follows the outline of ancient Roman walls.

name: Seville
wikipediaSummary: A historic Andalusian city renowned for its Moorish architecture, flamenco culture, and vibrant festivals. It served as a major port for trade with the Americas during Spain‚Äôs colonial era.
art: Diego Vel√°zquez - Old Woman Frying Eggs (the artist was born here)
Bartolom√© Esteban Murillo - The Immaculate Conception of Los Venerables
weirdFacts: The cathedral‚Äôs bell tower was originally built as a minaret.
An enormous wooden structure downtown is nicknamed 'the mushrooms.'
Orange trees line the streets, though their fruit is too bitter to eat.

name: Bilbao
wikipediaSummary: An industrial and cultural city in northern Spain, known for its modern transformation centered around the Guggenheim Museum. It is the economic heart of the Basque Country and a symbol of successful urban renewal.
art: Frank Gehry - Guggenheim Museum Bilbao (architectural artwork that transformed the city)
weirdFacts: A giant floral puppy sculpture guards the entrance to its iconic museum.
The city‚Äôs main football stadium has its own chapel for players and fans.
Local residents speak a language unrelated to any other in Europe.

name: Genoa
familyClue: The view from the campsite was stunning.
wikipediaSummary: A historic port city in northwestern Italy, once a powerful maritime republic and home to a long seafaring tradition. It is known for its medieval old town, Renaissance palaces, and role in global trade and exploration.
art: Giovanni Benedetto Castiglione - Baroque paintings depicting local maritime life
Rubens - Palazzi di Genova architectural drawings commissioned here
weirdFacts: Its old town is a maze of narrow alleys where sunlight barely reaches the ground.
A lighthouse here has guided ships since the 12th century.
A native explorer gave his name to an entire continent across the Atlantic.

name: Pisa
wikipediaSummary: A Tuscan city world-famous for its leaning bell tower and medieval architecture. Once a major maritime republic, it retains impressive monuments from its prosperous past.
art: Giovanni Pisano - Sculptures on the Cathedral fa√ßade
Benozzo Gozzoli - Frescoes in the Camposanto Monumentale
weirdFacts: The iconic tower began tilting before construction was even finished.
Its cathedral complex was designed to rival Venice and Genoa‚Äôs maritime glory.
Local students once used the tower to measure pendulum motion centuries before modern physics.

name: Verona
familyClue: We've been to the balcony here twice, once without the kids, once with.
wikipediaSummary: A northern Italian city famous for its Roman amphitheatre and association with Shakespeare‚Äôs 'Romeo and Juliet.' It combines Roman, medieval, and Renaissance architecture in a UNESCO-listed old town.
art: Paolo Veronese - Feast in the House of Levi (born near the city, depicting Venetian influence)
Altichiero da Zevio - Frescoes in San Zeno and San Giorgio churches
weirdFacts: A 2,000-year-old Roman amphitheatre still hosts opera performances today.
A balcony here is claimed‚Äîfalsely‚Äîto be Juliet‚Äôs, yet attracts millions of visitors.
During floods, ancient Roman streets become visible beneath modern ones.

name: Venice
familyClue: We camped a ferry-ride away from here.
wikipediaSummary: A lagoon city built on more than 100 islands, known for its canals, art, and architecture. It was a powerful maritime republic and remains one of the world‚Äôs most iconic and romantic destinations.
art: Canaletto - The Grand Canal and the Church of the Salute
Titian - Assumption of the Virgin (in situ in the Frari Church)
Giovanni Bellini - San Zaccaria Altarpiece
weirdFacts: The city has no roads‚Äîonly canals and footbridges.
It sinks about 1‚Äì2 millimeters every year.
Its glassmakers were once banished to a nearby island to prevent fires.

name: Turin
familyClue: We drove down a one-way tram track here and survived.
landmarks: Cathedral of Saint John the Baptist
wikipediaSummary: An elegant northern Italian city known for its Baroque architecture, chocolate, and automobile industry. It served as Italy‚Äôs first capital and remains a major center for culture and design.
art: Piero della Francesca - Polyptych of Saint Anthony (influenced local schools)
Carlo Mollino - Avant-garde architectural photography and design from the city
weirdFacts: A linen cloth kept here is believed by some to bear the image of a crucified man.
The first hard chocolate bar in history was invented here.
Its streets form a grid pattern dating back to ancient Roman planning.

name: Bari
familyClue: We embarked from here *ship horn noise*.
wikipediaSummary: A southern Italian port city on the Adriatic Sea known for its historic old town, seaside promenades, and as the resting place of Saint Nicholas. It is a key hub for trade and ferry routes to the Balkans.
weirdFacts: A crypt beneath a basilica holds relics of the saint who inspired Santa Claus.
Local grandmothers still hand-make pasta in the streets of the old town.
Its harbor has operated continuously since ancient Roman times.
festiveFacts: The relics of St. Nicolas reside here in the Basilica Di San Nicola. St Nicolas's habit of secret gift-giving gave rise to the folklore of Sinterklaas

name: Salzburg
familyClue: The chips are very clean here.
wikipediaSummary: A baroque Austrian city near the German border, famous as the birthplace of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and for its well-preserved Old Town, a UNESCO World Heritage Site surrounded by alpine scenery.
art: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart - Compositions inspired by his upbringing in the city
weirdFacts: A fortress overlooking the city has never been conquered in over 900 years.
The entire historic center is built from local salt trade wealth.
A famous musical film was shot in many of its gardens and streets.

name: Innsbruck
wikipediaSummary: A Tyrolean city surrounded by the Alps, known for its medieval architecture and as a world-class winter sports destination. It has twice hosted the Winter Olympics and remains a major mountain resort.
art: Michael Pacher - Altar artworks created for Tyrolean churches near the city
weirdFacts: It‚Äôs one of the few cities where you can ski in the morning and shop downtown by afternoon.
A 15th-century balcony here is covered in over 2,600 gilded copper tiles.
The Olympic torch has been lit here three separate times for major events.

name: Frankfurt
familyClue: We learned about Baby Shark here.
wikipediaSummary: A global financial hub in central Germany, known for its skyline, trade fairs, and as the birthplace of writer Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. It blends modern skyscrapers with medieval streets and museums along the river.
art: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe - Faust and other works written while living in the city
weirdFacts: Its skyline has earned it the nickname 'Mainhattan' due to its skyscrapers along the river.
An entire museum district lines the southern riverbank, each devoted to a different art or science theme.
The city‚Äôs airport is so large it has its own postal code.

name: Hamburg
familyClue: I believe the best art is here.
wikipediaSummary: A major port city in northern Germany with a rich maritime history. It is one of Europe‚Äôs largest harbors and a cultural center known for its architecture, canals, and vibrant music scene.
weirdFacts: It has more bridges than Venice and Amsterdam combined.
An enormous model railway attraction spans multiple countries and climates under one roof.
A Beatles residency in a local club helped launch their international career.

name: Split
wikipediaSummary: A coastal city on the Adriatic Sea, built around the ancient palace of the Roman Emperor Diocletian. It is a major cultural and economic center of Dalmatia, known for its mix of Roman, Venetian, and modern influences.
weirdFacts: The historic city core is built inside a Roman emperor‚Äôs retirement palace.
Residents once turned palace rooms into homes and shops, preserving them for centuries.
Ancient basements under the palace were used to film scenes for a famous fantasy TV series.

name: Dubrovnik
wikipediaSummary: A UNESCO World Heritage city on the Adriatic coast, famous for its medieval walls, marble streets, and baroque buildings. Once a powerful maritime republic, it is now one of Europe‚Äôs most picturesque destinations.
weirdFacts: Its city walls stretch nearly 2 kilometers and were never breached in medieval times.
A 14th-century pharmacy still operates within a monastery in the old town.
During the 1990s siege, locals held concerts inside damaged palaces to boost morale.

name: Zadar
familyClue: We missed the plane to here then visited a three-letter village nearby.
wikipediaSummary: An ancient port city on Croatia‚Äôs Dalmatian coast, blending Roman ruins, Venetian architecture, and modern design. It is known for its sunsets and innovative coastal installations that combine art, light, and sound.
art: Ivan Me≈°troviƒá - Sculptures inspired by Dalmatian heritage
weirdFacts: A modern installation here turns sea waves into musical tones.
It has one of the oldest continuously inhabited Roman forums on the Adriatic.
Its sunsets were famously praised by Alfred Hitchcock as the most beautiful in the world.

name: Antwerp
familyClue: A local was surprised that we visited here but lots of people used to stop by on their way through.
wikipediaSummary: A major port city in northern Belgium on the River Scheldt, known for its diamond district, vibrant fashion scene, and artistic heritage. It was home to the Baroque painter Peter Paul Rubens and remains one of Europe‚Äôs most important trading hubs.
weirdFacts: Legend says the city‚Äôs name comes from a giant whose hand was cut off and thrown into the river.
It hosts one of the world‚Äôs oldest printing presses, still preserved in its original building.
Its railway station is considered one of the most beautiful in the world, featuring a mix of stone, glass, and iron.

name: Gothenburg
wikipediaSummary: Sweden‚Äôs second-largest city and its main west coast port, founded by King Gustavus Adolphus. Known for its maritime heritage, innovative design scene, and strong links to music and technology.
art: Carl Larsson - Gothenburg Harbour
weirdFacts: Its fish market is built like a church, complete with stained glass windows.
A local amusement park attracts more annual visitors than the city‚Äôs population.
The city was originally fortified by Dutch engineers, giving it a canal system similar to Amsterdam.

name: Link√∂ping
familyClue: Ost! Gamla!
wikipediaSummary: A university and technology hub in southern Sweden known for its cathedral and aerospace industry. It combines medieval heritage with innovation, housing one of Scandinavia‚Äôs leading engineering universities.
art: M√•rten Eskil Winge - Thor's Fight with the Giants
weirdFacts: The city‚Äôs old quarter has been relocated and rebuilt as an open-air museum.
Aviation exhibits include a full-scale Cold War spy plane recovered from the Baltic Sea.
A massive wooden cathedral spire dominates the skyline and has stood for over 700 years.

name: Norrk√∂ping
familyClue: Famously renowned as the Manchester of this country.
wikipediaSummary: A riverside city in southeastern Sweden once called the 'Manchester of Sweden' for its textile industry. It has reinvented itself as a cultural and creative hub while preserving its 19th-century industrial architecture.
art: Bror Hjorth - Factory Workers
weirdFacts: The river running through the city powered textile mills for over 300 years.
A disused factory complex now houses art galleries, caf√©s, and tech startups.
A coastal installation nearby plays music generated by the motion of waves.

name: Gda≈Ñsk
wikipediaSummary: A historic Baltic port city in northern Poland known for its colorful merchant houses, shipyards, and maritime heritage. It played a key role in the start of World War II and the Solidarity movement that helped end communist rule in Eastern Europe.
art: Anton M√∂ller - The Allegory of Gda≈Ñsk
weirdFacts: A medieval crane on the waterfront was once powered by workers walking inside giant wooden wheels.
The city‚Äôs iconic liqueur contains genuine gold flakes.
It was once one of the wealthiest ports in the Hanseatic League.

name: Krak√≥w
wikipediaSummary: One of Europe‚Äôs oldest cities and Poland‚Äôs former royal capital, known for its medieval Old Town, Renaissance architecture, and deep cultural legacy. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a major intellectual and artistic center.
art: Jan Matejko - Prussian Homage
weirdFacts: A trumpeter plays a broken tune from a church tower every hour to commemorate a 13th-century attack.
A fire-breathing dragon statue guards the entrance to a cave beneath the castle hill.
The main market square is one of the largest medieval squares in Europe.

name: Kaliningrad
wikipediaSummary: An exclave of Russia on the Baltic Sea, located between Poland and Lithuania. Once known as K√∂nigsberg, it was a major Prussian and German city before becoming part of the Soviet Union after World War II. It is famed for its amber trade and complex history.
art: Caspar David Friedrich - The Sea of Ice
weirdFacts: It was once home to the philosopher Immanuel Kant, whose tomb still stands beside the cathedral.
An unfinished brutalist tower, nicknamed 'the Monster,' dominates the city skyline.
Large parts of the old city lie buried beneath postwar reconstruction and Soviet-era concrete.

name: Smolensk
wikipediaSummary: Smolensk is a historic city in western Russia, one of the oldest cities in the country. It has served as a crucial fortress and strategic point throughout Russian history, located on the Dnieper River near the Belarus border. The city played important roles in both the Napoleonic Wars and World War II.
weirdFacts: One of the oldest cities in the country, first mentioned in chronicles in 863 AD.
The city's massive fortress walls, built in the 16th century, are considered one of the strongest defensive structures in the country's history.
The city changed hands multiple times, leading to a unique blend of Orthodox and Catholic architectural styles.

name: Odessa
wikipediaSummary: A major port city on the Black Sea, founded in the late 18th century as part of the Russian Empire. Known for its elegant 19th-century architecture, multicultural history, and distinctive humor, it remains one of Ukraine‚Äôs most cosmopolitan cities.
art: Ivan Aivazovsky - The Ninth Wave
weirdFacts: The famous staircase leading to the port was designed to look longer when viewed from below.
A vast network of tunnels beneath the city was carved from limestone used in its construction.
The city‚Äôs sense of humor is so renowned it‚Äôs celebrated in an annual comedy festival.

name: Lviv
wikipediaSummary: A historic city in western Ukraine known for its baroque architecture, cobbled streets, and vibrant coffeehouse culture. Once part of Poland and the Austro-Hungarian Empire, it has a rich multicultural heritage and a thriving artistic scene.
art: Jan Styka - Panorama of the Battle of Rac≈Çawice
weirdFacts: The river that once ran through the city now flows entirely underground.
Locals boast of having more caf√©s per capita than almost any city in Europe.
A popular rooftop bar is themed after secret resistance fighters from wartime legend.

name: Rhodes
wikipediaSummary: A historic island city in the Aegean Sea, once home to the Colossus of Rhodes, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. Its walled medieval town, built by the Knights Hospitaller, is among the best preserved in Europe.
art: Colossus of Rhodes - Ancient bronze statue depicting the sun god Helios
weirdFacts: An ancient earthquake toppled one of the Seven Wonders of the World here.
The old town‚Äôs streets follow a medieval grid built by crusader knights.
Wild deer still roam near the harbor once guarded by one of the Seven Wonders.

name: Heraklion
wikipediaSummary: The largest city on Crete and gateway to the ancient Minoan civilization. It combines Venetian and Ottoman influences with archaeological treasures from Europe‚Äôs earliest palace complex at Knossos.
art: Minoan Fresco - Prince of the Lilies
weirdFacts: The nearby ancient palace once housed Europe‚Äôs first known flush toilets.
A myth says the island‚Äôs caves once sheltered the Minotaur‚Äôs labyrinth.
An old Venetian fortress guards the harbor, still standing after earthquakes and wars.

name: Sparta
wikipediaSummary: An ancient city-state in the Peloponnese, renowned for its militaristic society and discipline. Modern Sparta lies near the ruins of its classical predecessor, surrounded by olive groves and Mount Taygetus.
art: Ancient Greek Sculpture - Leonidas of Sparta
weirdFacts: Ancient citizens were forbidden to use gold or silver money, relying on iron bars instead.
All male citizens underwent harsh military training from the age of seven.
The city‚Äôs women were among the few in ancient Greece to own property and exercise publicly.

name: Izmir
familyClue: You had your hair straightened here.
wikipediaSummary: A major port city on Turkey‚Äôs Aegean coast, historically known as Smyrna. It is one of the country‚Äôs most liberal and cosmopolitan centers, blending ancient Greek, Roman, and Ottoman heritage.
art: Jean-L√©on G√©r√¥me - The Slave Market, Smyrna
weirdFacts: The city‚Äôs name has been changed multiple times across millennia, from Greek to Ottoman to modern Turkish.
A centuries-old bazaar here still follows the same street layout from Roman times.
An ancient castle overlooks the modern skyline, offering views once used for early fire signals.

name: Skopje
wikipediaSummary: The capital and largest city of North Macedonia, located on the Vardar River. It combines Ottoman, Byzantine, and modern influences, and has undergone large-scale reconstruction after a devastating earthquake in 1963.
art: Nikola Martinoski - Mother with Child
weirdFacts: A major earthquake destroyed 80% of the city in 1963, after which it was redesigned by a Japanese architect.
The main square features one of the tallest equestrian statues in Europe.
Locals joke that the city has more statues than people.

name: Tirana
wikipediaSummary: The capital and largest city of Albania, nestled between mountains and the Adriatic Sea. It has transformed from a gray communist-era city into a colorful and vibrant cultural hub.
art: Kol√´ Idromeno - Motra Tone
weirdFacts: Many drab communist-era buildings have been repainted in bright colors by a former artist-mayor.
The city‚Äôs most unusual landmark is a pyramid-shaped structure once dedicated to a dictator.
Underground bunkers built during the Cold War now serve as art galleries and museums.

name: Pristina
wikipediaSummary: The capital and largest city of Kosovo, known for its youthful energy, Ottoman heritage, and post-war renewal. It is a growing cultural and administrative center in the Balkans.
art: Esat Valla - The Butterfly
weirdFacts: The city‚Äôs library is famous for its bizarre concrete-and-glass bubble design.
A giant monument reading 'NEWBORN' is repainted each year with a new design.
The nearby bear sanctuary houses animals rescued from private restaurants.

name: Belgrade
wikipediaSummary: The capital of Serbia, located at the confluence of the Danube and Sava rivers. It has a long and turbulent history, combining Ottoman, Austro-Hungarian, and modern influences in its architecture and culture.
art: Paja Jovanoviƒá - The Takovo Uprising
weirdFacts: The city has been destroyed and rebuilt more than 40 times throughout history.
An underground network of Roman tunnels still exists beneath the old fortress.
A floating nightclub scene on the rivers operates almost every night of the week.

name: Sarajevo
wikipediaSummary: The capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, known for its religious and cultural diversity. It hosted the 1984 Winter Olympics and endured a long siege in the 1990s, emerging as a resilient symbol of coexistence.
art: Ismet Mujezinoviƒá - The Partisan School
weirdFacts: The event that triggered World War I happened on a bridge in the city center.
The skyline includes mosques, synagogues, and churches all within a few blocks.
Residents maintained an underground tunnel during wartime to bring in food and supplies.

name: Marseille
weirdFacts: The oldest city in France, founded by Greek sailors.
Home to one of France‚Äôs oldest ports, continuously active for over 2,600 years.
The port was the main entry point for immigrants to France for over a century.

name: Le Havre
weirdFacts: Completely rebuilt after World War II, earning UNESCO World Heritage status.
The city was designed by a single architect, Auguste Perret.
Home to the largest container port in France.

name: Gibraltar
founded: ancient times; captured by Britain in 1704
weirdFacts: The only place in Europe where wild monkeys live freely.
Has its own international airport with a road crossing the runway.
The territory is only 6.7 square kilometers but has its own currency.

name: Valencia
landmarks: Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias
weirdFacts: Home to the Holy Grail, according to local legend.
The birthplace of paella, originally a peasant dish.
Has a unique festival where giant papier-m√¢ch√© figures are burned.

name: Granada
weirdFacts: The last Muslim kingdom in Spain fell here in 1492.
Home to one of the most visited monuments in Spain.
The city has a unique tradition of free tapas with every drink.

name: Cologne
weirdFacts: The cathedral took over 600 years to complete.
Home to the world‚Äôs oldest perfume brand, created in the 18th century.
The city's carnival is one of the largest street festivals in Europe.

name: Essen
weirdFacts: Home to the world's largest board game festival.
The city was once the coal mining capital of Europe.
Has a UNESCO World Heritage site that was a former coal mine.

name: Doncaster
familyClue: The southiest part of the North.
weirdFacts: Once a major Roman fort.
Its racecourse hosted the first recorded 'St Leger Stakes' horse race in 1776.
The world-famous Mallard steam locomotive, which still holds the speed record for steam trains, was built here in 1938.

name: Sheffield
familyClue: We used to take the train together here in the morning sometimes.
weirdFacts: Known as the 'Steel City' for pioneering stainless steel and cutlery production.
It has more trees per person than any other city in Europe.
Half the city lies within a national park ‚Äî the Peak District.

name: Liverpool
familyClue: Do you like, have a car, though?
weirdFacts: Birthplace of The Beatles, whose legacy still attracts millions of tourists.
Home to two major football clubs with stadiums less than a mile apart.
Its waterfront is a UNESCO World Heritage Site modelled on New York‚Äôs skyline.

name: Buxton
familyClue: You love to visit here by yourself.
weirdFacts: Famous for its natural thermal spring water bottled and sold worldwide.
It is Britain‚Äôs highest market town, over 300 meters above sea level.
The Georgian Crescent was inspired by the Royal Crescent in Bath.

name: Cardiff
familyClue: We used to be very late visiting this place for Chinese takeaway.
weirdFacts: The smallest capital city in mainland Europe by area.
Home to one of the world‚Äôs oldest record shops, founded in 1894.
Its bay area was once the world‚Äôs largest coal-exporting port.

name: Groningen
familyClue: A friend of yours went to university here.
weirdFacts: The city‚Äôs university is older than many European nations, founded in 1614.
Cars are banned from much of the city centre, making it one of the most bicycle-friendly places in the world.
The local accent is so distinctive that it‚Äôs nearly unintelligible to some native speakers.

name: Palermo
cuisine: Pasta con le sarde (pasta with sardines)
weirdFacts: A series of underground catacombs beneath the city contains thousands of naturally mummified bodies dressed in their finest clothes.
The local opera house is one of the largest in Europe and appeared in the final scene of The Godfather Part III.
The city has been ruled by Phoenicians, Romans, Arabs, Normans, and Spaniards ‚Äî all of whom left visible marks on its architecture.

name: Tunis
familyClue: We needed two taxis to get around here.
cuisine: Brik (fried pastry with egg and tuna)
weirdFacts: The city stands near the ruins of ancient Carthage, once Rome‚Äôs greatest rival.
Its medina is a UNESCO World Heritage site with over 700 historic monuments packed into narrow alleys.
A 9th-century mosque here still operates as both a religious and educational center ‚Äî one of the oldest in the Muslim world.

name: Gruy√®res
familyClue: We have visited here twice, once without the kids, once with.
weirdFacts: The HR Giger Museum here, designed by the creator of the Alien films‚Äô aesthetic, sits beside a medieval castle.
The town lends its name to one of the country's most famous cheeses, which is still made by traditional methods nearby.
Every summer, local herders parade cows adorned with flowers down from alpine pastures in a centuries-old tradition.

name: Bern
weirdFacts: The city‚Äôs name is said to come from a bear, the first animal hunted by its founder ‚Äî and real bears still live in a riverside enclosure here.
Einstein developed parts of his theory of relativity while working at the local patent office.
Its medieval old town is built on a loop of the River Aare, giving it natural protection on three sides.

name: Basel
weirdFacts: The city sits on the borders of three countries and its tram system even crosses them.
One of Europe‚Äôs oldest and largest art fairs began here in the 1970s and still draws collectors from around the world.
A local carnival starts at precisely 4:00 a.m. with all lights turned off, leaving only lanterns and piccolos to guide the crowd.

name: Zermatt
familyClue: We went with your parents but stayed in a separate hotel.
wikipediaSummary: A car-free alpine resort village at the foot of the Matterhorn in southern Switzerland, known for year-round mountaineering and skiing. It is reached by mountain railway and surrounded by some of the highest peaks in the Alps.
weirdFacts: Most streets are served by silent electric taxis and horse-drawn carriages instead of regular cars.
A nearby peak‚Äôs first ascent in 1865 ended tragically when a rope snapped, sending four climbers to their deaths.
The highest cable car station in Europe sits above the village at nearly 3,900 meters.

name: Faroe Islands
cuisine: Grind og spik (pilot whale and blubber)
wikipediaSummary: An autonomous North Atlantic archipelago under the sovereignty of Denmark, known for dramatic cliffs, grass-roofed houses, and a unique Nordic culture influenced by both Norse and Celtic traditions.
weirdFacts: Sheep outnumber people by nearly two to one.
There are no forests because the wind is too strong for tall trees to grow.
Mail is delivered by helicopter to some of the most remote islands.

name: Shetland Islands
wikipediaSummary: A subarctic archipelago in the Northern Isles of Scotland, located between the Orkney Islands and Norway. Known for Norse heritage, rugged coastlines, and the Up Helly Aa fire festival.
weirdFacts: A Viking-themed fire festival lights up the winter night every January.
The local ponies have been exported worldwide for over a century.
At midsummer, it stays light nearly all night long.

name: Patras
wikipediaSummary: Greece's third-largest city and the regional capital of Western Greece, located in the northern Peloponnese. Known as the 'Gate to the West' due to its busy port, it hosts one of Europe's largest carnivals and was the European Capital of Culture in 2006.
weirdFacts: The city hosts one of Europe's largest carnivals every February, attracting hundreds of thousands of visitors.
Its port manages more than half of all foreign sea-passenger transportation in the country.
The Rio-Antirrio Bridge connecting it to the mainland is one of the world's longest multi-span cable-stayed bridges.

name: Dully
wikipediaSummary: A small village in the Vaud canton of Switzerland, located on the shores of Lake Geneva. Known for its picturesque setting and historic ch√¢teau.

name: Oulu
wikipediaSummary: A city in northern Finland, known as the 'Capital of Northern Scandinavia'. It's a major technology hub and university city, located near the Gulf of Bothnia.

name: Rovaniemi
wikipediaSummary: The capital of Lapland and the official hometown of Santa Claus. Located on the Arctic Circle, it's a gateway to Finnish Lapland and known for its winter tourism.
weirdFacts: The city is the official hometown of Santa Claus.
It was completely destroyed in WWII and rebuilt according to a plan by Alvar Aalto.
The Arctic Circle runs through Santa Claus Village, just outside the city.
